content: The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 may temporarily suspend motor fuel taxes. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 proposes a temporary suspension of various fuel taxes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 suggests a temporary suspension of certain fuel taxes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes exceptions for specific types of fuel and defines the suspension period based on gasoline prices. Additionally, it ensures that trust fund deposits are maintained despite any reduction in tax rates. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 proposes a temporary suspension of fuel taxes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, with exceptions for certain fuels and a defined suspension period based on gasoline prices. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the enactment date of the Act. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the enactment date of the Act. SEC. 3. REPEAL OF EXPENSING FOR CERTAIN REFINERIES. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 proposes repealing section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, with technical amendments to related sections. The repeal transfers equivalent tax liability to the Highway Trust Fund. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 proposes repealing section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code, transferring tax liabilities to the Highway Trust Fund based on estimates made by the Secretary of the Treasury. Adjustments will be made for prior estimates, and the amendments apply to property placed in service after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. FLOOR STOCK REFUNDS. SEC. 4. FLOOR STOCK REFUNDS. In General, a tax referred to in section 4081(f)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 imposed on any liquid before the enactment of this Act will be credited or refunded to the taxpayer if the liquid is held by a dealer and intended for sale. Time for Filing Claims requires a claim to be filed within 6 months of the enactment of this Act, and the dealer must submit a request for refund or credit to the taxpayer within 3 months. The taxpayer must repay or obtain consent from the dealer for a credit claimed before 3 months after the date. No credit or refund is allowed for liquid in retail stocks. Definitions of "dealer" and "held by a dealer" are based on section 6412 of the Code. Rules similar to section 6412 apply. SEC. 5. FLOOR STOCKS TAX. Imposition of Tax: A floor stocks tax is imposed on taxable liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, calculated as the excess tax compared to what would have been paid under the Internal Revenue Code. Liability and payment methods are outlined, with the tax due within 6 months of the floor stocks tax date. Definitions clarify that a liquid is considered held by a person if title has passed to them. The term "taxable liquid" refers to any liquid subject to a tax under section 4081(a)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code on the floor stocks tax date, defined as the day after the suspension period. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury. Exceptions include no tax on liquid held for exempt uses, in vehicle tanks, or certain amounts of fuel. On the floor stocks tax date, no tax is imposed on liquid held if the amount does not exceed 2,000 gallons, and the person submits required information to the Secretary. Fuel exempt from tax is not considered. Controlled groups are treated as one person for tax purposes. The floor stock taxes imposed by subsection (a) are subject to all provisions of law applicable to taxes imposed by chapter 31 or 32 of the tax code. This includes penalties and other laws, applying as if the taxes were imposed by such chapter. Principles similar to those for corporations under common control also apply to nonincorporated persons under common control. The Federal Trade Commission will monitor gasoline prices in the US, determining the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline monthly. Reports will be submitted to Congress and made available to the public. Additionally, a Commission on Gas Price Relief will be established. The Speaker of the House of Representatives will establish a Commission on Gas Price Relief within three months of this Act. The Commission, comprised of 9 Members, will study the causes of high oil prices and submit a report to the House of Representatives within 1 year. The report will include revenue raisers to replenish the Treasury for any loss resulting from the suspension of Federal excise taxes on motor fuels. The Commission on Gas Price Relief will consist of 9 Members, including appointees from the Committee on Ways and Means and the Committee on Energy and Commerce. The Chairmen of these committees will serve as co-chairs of the Commission.
